title: Flintlock: The Siege of Dawn
review:
really boring 
uneven performance
combat and movement feels very floaty and imprecise
looks bad technically and dull aesthetically
intolerable dialogue

title: Flintlock: The Siege of Dawn
review:
had a really fun playthrough actually. 
Just a 2-3 days blast with challenging mecanics.

Great design and fighting elements. Platinum it in 18h.

Worth every 20$.  7,5/10

title: Flintlock: The Siege of Dawn
review: Really fun game, no complaints. Plays like the newer God of War games mixed with a pinch of Souls. Not nearly as hard as Souls games with a much more comprehensible story. Really enjoyed this, doesn't overstay its welcome either.

title: Flintlock: The Siege of Dawn
review: Fun gameplay. Great settings. Awesome enemies. Not enough bosses. Main character doesn't feel compelling enough - they could have focused more on her being more likeable. Nevertheless a good game with lots of fun.

title: Flintlock: The Siege of Dawn
review:
Just beat this. Had a good time. If you want a souls-lite with good mobility and can take a little jank, you won't go wrong here. The writing's good too (a handful of characters are just... there, but some get some more love).

From the middle on, you're basically a tank rolling over the poor undead, and only a few difficult encounters and the major bosses pose a real threat. Final boss is a real pain in the ass, but that's to be expected (also crashed my game twice while the entire rest of the game was stable).

Exploration is rewarding, combat abilities are fun, and the area design can be quite pretty. Yeah, give this a go!

title: Flintlock: The Siege of Dawn
review: Pretty bad pacing issues, both with story and level presentation, but the overall gameplay is enjoyable. Parrying feels good and the boss fights were really fun. I do however, wish that there were more boss fights, and also less filler/exploration time between them. I didn't feel enticed to engage with pretty much any of the side content. (7/10)

title: Flintlock: The Siege of Dawn
review:
This game has made me realize that reviewers are too finicky, too demanding, and overly spoiled by today’s standards that no game ever achieves excellence in. I am so disappointed in the reviewers. I read them, I waited to get the game, got it on sale and it is just a great and fun game. 

In a period of time when AAA games are failing us in performance like dragons dogma 2 this game outperforms. In a period of time where AAA games like Skull and Bones gameplay misses the mark this game out performs. In a period of time where AAA games have an absolutely terrible story and set of characters like Forespoken this game out performs. It’s fine to call it a AA B rated game. That’s ok, but it’s top class AA where it out shines many AAA games. These devs deserve support. Thank you for this game.

And for Lenovo Go users, I run it at 1200p at high settings and it runs amazing.

title: Flintlock: The Siege of Dawn
review: Has it's shortcomings, but overall fun/satisfying combat with great voice acting. Did have a few game crashes, but loading back in was fast. Game did feel short. Could benefit from NG+. Overall would recommend. Good for a AA game.

title: Flintlock: The Siege of Dawn
review:
Disregarding its controversy, the game isn't actually bad.

There are aspects to the combat, gameplay, and world-building that should be commended, but quest-ending glitches and some graphical pop-ins do diminish the overall experience.

Personally, I try to look for a game's positives more than its weaknesses, so I'd say Flintlock is a solid 6.5/10.

title: Flintlock: The Siege of Dawn
review: I found this a very approachable game as someone with no soulslike experience. Combat is interesting and requires you to pay attention to animations and mechanics without ever feeling unfair or crushingly difficult. Checkpoints are plentiful, upgrades feel useful, and the game is short enough that I didn't get sick of any of the side content. It's not a life-changing game but it was enjoyable and worthwhile for me.

title: Flintlock: The Siege of Dawn
review:
Fantastic game. Easy 9/10
Some minor audio and performance issues here and there but overall highly recommended.

title: Flintlock: The Siege of Dawn
review:
Sifu, Ashen 都是A44有創意的GOOD GAME, 但這遊戲沒有那種驚喜
地圖感覺空蕩蕩, 沒有很多互動元素, 有點感覺未開發完(但也沒有不認真的地方), 但沒有法環那樣空

戰鬥:
戰鬥感覺得有點似戰神但比戰神OP(也沒有很易)而多樣, 也沒有耐力限制...
有完美擋格,  完美閃避
應該的都有

長度:
比一般長遠(超過30小時), 最高難度

價錢:
超值! 即使原價也是

難度:
沒有打過魂類的人應該會受不了, 特別是最後王

title: Flintlock: The Siege of Dawn
review: Quintessential good-but-not-quite-great AA effort, lots of character and promise, very fun combat. Would LOVE to see what the devs could do with a sequel, but happy with what we've got.

title: Flintlock: The Siege of Dawn
review:
Straight-forward action adventure with soulslite elements. 
[7/10]

+ unique fantasy setting
+ fast-paced tactical combat with a smooth hybrid fighting style
+ fun casual platforming puzzles
+ rewarding exploration in adequate level design
– low variety in build options and enemies
– protagonist has superficial thoughts and dialogues
– mediocre to decent voice acting with a tons of forgetful characters
– boring narrative and script with shallow quests

For this price it offers more fun gameplay than most AAA games, while being equally shallow.

title: Flintlock: The Siege of Dawn
review:
I came to Flintlock as a huge fan of the developer's previous game Ashen. This game is very different from that, despite both having soul-like elements in their design. 

Where Ashen was an open-world game with a huge focus on exploration, and coop. Flintlock is closer to the modern God of War duologies with how it designs its semi-open world areas. It has no multiplayer, and is much lighter with its souls-like elements, properly calling itself a Souls lite. Its combat is closer to an outright action game, and I am all for it. Your movement is incredibly smooth and fluid, with one of the best-feeling triple jumps I have used in an action game. I find myself trying to use it when playing other third-person games it's so natural to use. 

Its mixing of guns and melee is very impactful, with both allowing for fast-paced defense with parries. I am very glad they did not try to use a stamina system, as between magic and guns being restored over time and from melee hits respectively, there is little downtime in combat. The gear and skill trees give you some personalization with your playstyle, but you are far more limited than a traditional souls like. You *will* use a mix of magic melee and guns if you want to succeed. 

The story is not amazing, but still good and much more cinematic than the subtle storytelling of Ashen, with good performances from all the actors. Nor and her magic fox companion Enki, along with her crew of Sappers make up a good cast. With side quests for each of your camp members that will feel familiar to anyone who played Ashen. 

The game is short, a normal run only being around 15 hours, with my extra time coming from playing about half the game on hard and replaying it to get all achievements, as well as spending a decent amount of time on the Sabo minigame. I have seen some hate for this mini-game online. But I miss when games used to throw in a mini-game just for fun. And it's easy to ignore other than its strangely brutal achievement. I would take it over a hacking mini-game that is forced into gameplay any day.


Overall Flintlock is everything I want from an AA game. Its combat could easily hold up a much larger AAA game, even if its other elements show its lower budget and the small size of its developer.

I think games like this, Stellar Blade, and Black Myth: Wukong show you can take elements of souls like combat, but use them along with more traditional action systems to great effect. 

I highly recommend Flintlock to action game fans, and souls like fans if you know what you are getting into.

title: Flintlock: The Siege of Dawn
review:
[h1]Hell Yeah![/h1]

[h2]Flintlock: The Siege of Dawn is a beautifully crafted action narrative game that feels so good to play![/h2]
[i]And it's made in good ol' New Zealand ;) [/i]

[h3]THE COMBAT:[/h3]
The combat is so smooth! The action is fast paced and varied with the impressive amount of enemy and weapon types that feels fluid and fun! The animations and visuals are stunning and the skills are actually quite impactful. Swinging at an enemy and then canceling their attack with a flintlock shot feels super satisfying to me! 

[h3]THE BOSSES:[/h3]
The bosses in Flintlock were, for the most part, pretty damn good! Their designs were unique and interesting, but I found that near the end the bosses felt a little too easy (I played on 'Normal'). There were a few repeat bosses but they weren't repeated enough to be a problem to me. Each boss felt fair and beatable which is always a good thing!

[h3]THE STORY:[/h3]
The story of Flintlock is pretty good! while at times it can feel somewhat generic and predictable, I found myself not caring about that because Nor and Enki's relationship and banter kept me engaged. The voice acting would slightly vary in quality for the other characters, but Nor and Enki were awesome through the whole game! The other characters were interesting too and the side quests were very enjoyable! Side Quest Spoilers: [spoiler]I particularly enjoyed the [b][i]To The Forgotten[/i][/b] and [b][i]The Family Condition[/i][/b] side quests![/spoiler]

[h3]THE WORLD:[/h3]
The open world aspects of Flintlock were perfect for me! The world felt big enough that I could explore and get some cool armour or weapons, but it wasn't too big that I felt lost (like a lot of games have had recently). The activities around the world were fun and rewarding and I enjoyed every minute of exploring it!

[h3]THE OTHER STUFF:[/h3]
The performance was general pretty good (I averaged around 90 fps with max settings) but I did notice that in some areas the fps would drop significantly, but after a few seconds it would fix itself. I also noticed that the audio would sometimes be weirdly quiet in comparison the the rest of the audio but these will most likely get fixed in an update!

[h3]CONCLUSION:[/h3]
Overall, I found Flintlock: The Siege of Dawn to be an extremely enjoyable and highly polished indie action narrative game! The game felt similar to some AAA games like God of War (2018) but still managed to feel unique and stand on it's own legs! 

[h2]The team at A44 Games should be extremely proud of what they were able to achieve and I can't wait to see what's next![/h2]

title: Flintlock: The Siege of Dawn
review: I enjoyed my time with this game, overall flawed but really fun experience. The VA work really helped sell the characters despite them being fairly underwritten imo. The art design was beautiful, the sound design had some really weird issues of voices and actions sounding really far away even though they were close to the protagonist which was odd. The gameplay itself was fun, getting a parry off and blasting an enemy in the face with a shot was really satisfying. I enjoyed the reputation system. saving up the percentage and being rewarded with how well you played with more was a really cool feature. Having limited resources to upgrade weapons and armor was something that should have been communicated to the player more effectively. The ending and overall story once again did feel really underwritten, not quite complete. Maybe there will be a dlc to flesh out more of the world overall but who knows. A recommend from me.

title: Flintlock: The Siege of Dawn
review:
The good:

- Art and design
- Fighting system
- Locations

The bad:

- After the first half the game feels rushed. Final level has gorgeous aesthetics, but the mobs are from the first level?!
- Very limited items. I had only two hatchets throughout the whole game
- Story is mediocre at best

title: Flintlock: The Siege of Dawn
review: This is a great game. feel bad that it got bad press because its one of my favorite games of the year.hope more people get to enjoy  it.

title: Flintlock: The Siege of Dawn
review: Flintlock: The Siege of Dawn offers a thrilling experience with its fast-paced movement mechanics and challenging difficulty options, but it suffers from obstructive invisible walls that hinder exploration. The mantling system is often finicky, with minor bumps halting your progress, and while the story is decent and town conversations are entertaining, repetitive and annoying voice lines like "What's that then" can quickly wear thin. Overall, the game’s engaging combat and lively dialogue are overshadowed by frustrating movement issues and a lack of fluid exploration. Still worth playing, but there are definitely better options out there. Try Ashen if you haven't.

title: Flintlock: The Siege of Dawn
review:
Upvoted the game but it has issues. 
1 - phantom walls that block you from taking a short cut across the map are annoying. You MUST find a specific route to get to some places even though I found a way to get there faster.
2 - What's the point of saying I can survive large falls if I do a double jump right before I hit the ground, if you're going to say I died when I jump off a ledge that the game deems "too far"? rhetorical..it's not fair to the gamer.
3 - Why have areas mapped out on the map I can never go to? It's like they never finished the game or removed things to have it later as DLC. They might be in those areas. Islands and map areas near the outer edge seem to have things to do but I can't get to them. I searched and searched for doorways or access points and nothing. Sometimes it forces you to use the skull jump points or you can't get places.  
4 - DO NOT go to the last (3rd) map travel area to go after Uru until you're sure you're ready. I passed/activated a ton of load stones and when I got to Uru's area, I tried to go back to the camp and it said i'ts disabled??? I have unfinished side quests I can never do.
BTW once you fight Uru, the game just ends. You can't go back and finish side quests.
The graphics and gameplay overall are great though. I used an unlimited potions cheat and had fun with it because it also applies to grenades. You can then throw as many as you like. 
It really does look good and plays fine but it has annoyances and things players need to know like, make sure you find everything in side quests before leaving an area to travel. This only applies to people who want to find all the hidden stuff and side quests. 
Why are there like 20 slots for guns, grenades, etc etc and there appears to be very few of them. I found a whole 3 helmets. I assume all the other armor set items are in those hidden map areas. I tried to upgrade one axe but it said I didn't have one rare resource. I never saw that resource anywhere. 
It was still fun to play.

title: Flintlock: The Siege of Dawn
review:
[h1] Sweet Baby Inc's best work yet. [/h1]

First things first: While Flintlock definitely has some soulslike trappings, mainly in the way it handles death, it is really just a fairly competent riff on God of War 2019 -- if Kratos had a double jump and an air dash. 
Yes, there's a parry and a dodge roll but there's no stamina bar you have to nurse and you can actually pause the game ;) 

While the combat doesn't feel especially good, the graphics aren't anything to write home about (except when they sometimes are) and the story is flimsy at best, this game just offers so many mechanics and they all tie together rather elegantly. Shooting, stabbing, throwing grenades, and magic are just a few ways you can dispatch enemies -- and the game actively encourages you to switch it up by upping your score multiplier, almost like it's Devil May Cry. 

So yes, the game is good. Some great loot, beautiful music and chill vistas -- for less than 30 bucks I paid it's more than worth it.

Now, I know, the question that's been burning on everyone's mind: is the game woke? 
Just kidding, I don't know. But you know what's certainly not woke? Touching grass.

7/10

title: Flintlock: The Siege of Dawn
review:
Based on my experience so far, this game is quite impressive. It effectively combines several elements from the God of War series with the challenge characteristic of Dark Souls. However, it is important to note that it is not a fully Souls-like game. Playing on the hard difficulty, as I do, often results in being defeated in just 2 - 3 hits.

The combat system is fluid and enjoyable, with a seamless integration of both melee and ranged combat, which adds to the overall excitement. Additionally, the game features platforming elements that provide a refreshing break after intense combat sequences, however, it feels a little rushed sometimes.

At this point, i can recommend this game to anyone who enjoys Souls-like experiences or titles similar to God of War.


[url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/44938427/]Check out my other reviews here[/url]

title: Flintlock: The Siege of Dawn
review: Flintlock: The Siege of Dawn is a decent AA Souls-Lite that doesn't overstay it's welcome and has some pretty fun platforming mixed in with some decent (albeit clunky,) combat. Stories borderline non-existent but what little is there was O'Kay. Definitely recommend on a decent sale..... unless of course you're some capital G Gamer who can't deal with minorities in your Vidya Game because "reasons."

title: Flintlock: The Siege of Dawn
review: Decent Soulslike. Very finicky with regards to parry timing, more difficult than the average Souls clone. Need to be very patient with it to get much out of it, but it's polished and enjoyable all things considered.

title: Flintlock: The Siege of Dawn
review: I really liked the first 3/4 of the game, but starting with the Dukmar boss the end feels kind of rushed and therefore the later bosses are very grindy (lots of hitpoints) and not fun for me.

title: Flintlock: The Siege of Dawn
review:
Flintlock is not a bad game.  I can understand people being wary of buying it seeing the SBI involvement and rightfully so as SBI has a track record of any game they are involved in being pretty awful, and I went in expecting to hear all about colonizers and the poor struggling main character who had it tough and happily got none of that (though more of her later).  I played on the hardest difficulty (possessed) and the beginning was quite challenging when I had no combat options and I would die in a few hits, but as the game went on it became more balanced.  
Gameplay would be most similar to 2018 God of War; you have your standard melee attacks, block, dodge and parry.  Enki your stand in Atreus has his stun attacks and his large rune attack.  You have the titular flintlock which is used much like the firearms in Bloodborne for interrupting attacks, and grenades of various types for extra flavor though difficult to get to in the middle of combat since it occupies the healing flask slot.  You have three armor slots (Head, Shoulder, Hand) and five different armor sets.  The armor provides no statistical benefit (no extra HP, no extra attack power), but changes the way the characters plays (extra distance on melee attacks, slow down time if you dodge last second, etc.).  The leveling system is three interlinked trees (Firearms, Melee, Magic) and each node gives a new skill or enhancement to existing skills with each node in a tree giving a small boost to the damage from that tree to a maximum of 140%.
The game takes a while for the combat to really show itself and I would say I started to appreciate it around when I got my first piece of armor which I believe was a few hours into the game.  From then on things felt balanced where I could clear towns without dying, but if I was lazy I could be killed easily (this may vary depending on the difficulty you play on).
The characters are mostly enjoyable though the main character seems to start off as annoying and headstrong but fairly quickly matures.  Enki was great though having him constantly tell me I am a natural after 20 hours (days/weeks? in game time) of going through the slip gates got old.  The rest of the sapper crew were a mixed bunch, but by the end I enjoyed them for what they were, old man father figure, stoic guy, other guy, and bitchy chick that respects you.
The story was enjoyable but I swear this game was meant to be another 25% longer or so as some plot points (betrayals) are immediately glossed over in cut-scenes; e.g. character A betrays character B's trust, in the immediate cut-scene another character says they've been talking among themselves and when you get back to gameplay it's all good.  It's very jarring having these moments that feel important suddenly get shuffled off with no time to digest.  The world is interesting, the enemies are fine (some better than others and the later ones better than the early ones), the music was enjoyable.
There are bugs and I have doubts they will be fixed, they don't stop you from completing the game but they are real annoying.  One bug is that a horde (large group of normal enemies you can clear for extra exp/money) could not be completed as the final enemy would not count toward the total group health and so when all of the enemies were killed the encounter never ended.  The second bug I ran into was that on the enemy turn in the Sebo mini-game if you open and close the special piece menu while hovering over a special piece you will constantly remove turns from the enemy even giving the enemy negative turns meaning as soon as they make their first move they lose the game (I hated Sebo so once I realized this was still a thing I abused it).  The third bug I encountered was that after winning a game of Sebo the game stopped asking if I wanted to keep playing Sebo and just assumed I did, I could not escape the mini-game even if I forfeit the match and so had to alt f4 out of the game (though winning the match had been saved).  I had one crash on the final boss during a cutscene in between phases which made me start the whole fight over, but did not set my health or resources to pre-fight conditions, but that was my one game crash.  I had quite a few bad stutters while playing which did sometimes lead to me dying (less than ten more than five).
Overall Flintlock isn't going to revolutionize anything, but if you are looking for a not quite open world (again like GoW 2018) with a decent combat system and ok world, some decent characters, for a decent price then you could do worse than this.

title: Flintlock: The Siege of Dawn
review:

title: Flintlock: The Siege of Dawn
review:

11/10

in seriousness now i've played it more. Nor has a real issue with refusing to do things if she is already in an animation [dodging needs to be more of a priority than a random overhead swing babe] [same with firing a gun for attack interruptions]
but the gameplay is fun, engaging and the world/lore is gorgeous. It's a shame it never took off [also don't look at the community page, the weirdos hate this game] but i very much recommend

review:

title: Flintlock: The Siege of Dawn
review:
Not every game needs to be a masterpiece in order to be an amazing fun time. If you're looking for a entertaining action game, with some challenge and "Souls" elements, give this game a chance!

I rarely write review on games, but with this one I felt compelled to do it. There's a whole discourse surrounding this game that obnubilates what's really important in video games: HAVING FUN.

First of all, let's adress the elephant in the room, the "SBI thing": There's no politics in this game, there's no forced inclusion. There's nothing to hate about the game being woke or bigot. Nothing. This is a "popcorn videogame" in the best possible way. It takes itself serious enough just to avoid those Josh-Whedon-like jokes.

The combat is a mix between Bloodborne/Lies of P and God of War, clearly less polished than these, but with a way better designed companion mechanics than the latter. You parry with block or gun, depending on your enemies attacks and resource management, and you're encouraged to sinchronize your attacks with Enki (the fox companion) for boosts and benefits. There's also some lite character building that emerges from armor/weapon/skills synergy.

If you want to have the "Souls" experience, the hard mode is very well balanced to what veterans are used to. You can not brute force through the enemies, you will need to be strategic about combat. There is some jank here and there, particularly in the plataforming, but the movement in combat is very well polished. Progression is also well acomplished, you might have to "farm" to unlock all skills, but the gameplay changing ones are very low in the tree.

Overall the game si solid fun, IMO well worth the AA price asked for it.

title: Flintlock: The Siege of Dawn
review: This game have fun combat but  grindy boring achievement

title: Flintlock: The Siege of Dawn
review: it was ok good thing it was short that what she said no but a solid game

title: Flintlock: The Siege of Dawn
review:
Bought on sale and really enjoyed this game from start to finish.
I really appreciate that it's not too long, I think there are like 5 real bosses - but the devs avoided dragging the game out too long with filler bullshit. Fun risk/reward mechanics, feels like a hybrid of God of War and Souls-like (but not punishing), with more mobility, crafting isn't over-complicated (there are like 3 resource types), and you build up the skill tree at a consistent pace through the game.
Would buy again

title: Flintlock: The Siege of Dawn
review: Great and non woke. Really. It really is! Fun time!
